array.string: Much of our sense of competence comes in reflection about our lives not just about the actions we take. ― The Charge by Brendon Burchard
Writing a journal not only lets you see where you’ve been, but can be a window to your future.
Memories are preserved when written down.
Preserve your memories.
“Be yourself. Above all, let who you are, what you are, what you believe, shine through every sentence you write, every piece you finish.” — John Jakes
Freewriting is a fast method of thinking on paper.
Spill your mind into Day One, without any judgment or stopping.
Talk to yourself in your writing.
Quality can be distilled later by editing.
Write the way you think.
Get your raw thoughts.
Use the Calendar view to enter memories and events in the past.
Focus on writing about one specific idea or moment in detail.
Journaling about yourself is memorizing your steps.
Write what you know.
Keep your journal private.
Don't worry about grammar or typos. If this bothers you, don't re-read your entries for a while.
Write two paragraphs. The first paragraph: A sentence for everything noteworthy you've done that day. The second paragraph: What you've been thinking about, activities and, thoughts.
“Writers are the custodians of memory, and that’s what you must become if you want to leave some kind of record of your life…” — William Zinsser
“In Hollywood, when people die they don't say, 'Did he leave a will?' but 'Did he leave a diary?'” — Liza Minnelli
“Keep a diary, and someday it'll keep you.” — Mae West
“Every person should keep a journal and every person can keep a journal.” — Spencer W. Kimball
Day One can be a logbook to keep track of the little details of your day. Who, what, where types of details. Who you met, what you did, where you went, etc.
It may seem tedious at first to add these details, but future readers will be grateful for your efforts.
Be sure to include complete information: names (first and last), dates (including the year), and places.
Your story should be written now while it is fresh and while the true details are available.
After the writer's death, reading his journal is like receiving a long letter.
A journal is a daily record of events or business; a private journal is usually referred to as a diary.
What are you thankful for today?
What do you crave and why?
The talents I have are…
What is your favorite time of day?
Over the weekend I will…
The perfect place in the whole world is…
What have you recently learned?
What are three things you wish you were better at?
Physical and mental health improvements occur when individuals write about emotional experiences.
Journal writing is a voyage to the interior.
By simply writing down your thoughts, they can magically disappear.
By writing about emotional or stressful experiences, your ability to concentrate can increase.
Day One is your private Twitter.
Copy-and-paste a recent email you wrote to someone into your journal.
Writing in a journal can give you increased attention and memory capacity.
Journal writing can give you longer lasting relationships.
Writing about your life leads to less worrying and anxiety.
The best way to improve your writing is by writing more.
Your journal is a vital record.
In addition to sharing thoughts and feelings, your journal is a record of your life’s events.
Don’t assume that people and events you know intimately will be familiar to your future readers.
Vary your entries—mix it up!
Make sure you write your feelings and thoughts about your life's events.
Don’t become obsessed with fact to the exclusion of emotion.
Don't give up!
No matter how much time has passed since your last entry, don't be discouraged. Start again—write today!
The truth should be told, but we should not emphasize the negative.
Your private journal should record the way you face up to challenges that beset you.
What is common to you is a banquet to someone else.
Write a letter to a loved one who has passed away.
Write a letter to your future self.
Write a letter to prepare for an important conversation.
Write a love letter.
What have you dreamed about lately?
Keeping a journal regularly can have an immense positive impact on the immune system.
What was the happiest moment of your life?
What was the saddest moment of your life?
Who have been the most important people in your life? Why?
Who has been the biggest influence on your life? What lessons did that person teach you?
What are the most important lessons you’ve learned in life?
What is your earliest memory?
How has your life been different than what you’d imagined?
How would you like to be remembered?
Do you have any regrets?
Are there any words of wisdom you’d like to pass along?
What are you proudest of in your life?
How has your life been different than what you’d imagined?
What lessons have you learned from your relationships?
How was your relationship with your parents?
How would you describe yourself as a child? Were you happy?
What are your best and worst memories of childhood?
Did you have a nickname? How’d you get it?
Who were your best friends? What were they like?
How would you describe a perfect day when you were young?
What did you think your life would be like when you were older?
Do you have any favorite stories from your childhood?
Did you enjoy school?
What kind of student were you?
Write about a teacher or teachers who had a particularly strong influence on your life.
Do you have any favorite stories from school?
What was one of the most profound moments of your life?
Who were your favorite relatives?
What is your full name? How was it picked for you?
When and where were you born?
Who do people say you look like? Why?
Describe the house your family lived in when you were born. Where was it located?
Are there any special stories about you as a young child?
What is your favorite baby photo of yourself?
Do you know what your first words were? How old were you?
When and where did you take your first steps alone?
What is your earliest memory?
Did/Do you have any pets?
Did you grow up in the town of your birth?
What do you know about the home town and neighborhood you grew up in?
Tell about the house you lived in during your childhood. Do you remember the addresses or phone numbers?
Describe the house you best remember living in while growing up. Where was it located? Is it still there?
What physical traits did you inherit from each of your parents?
Do you have any memorable employment stories?
Describe any childhood illnesses or injuries you had and treatments you received. Were you allergic to anything?
What jobs have your parents had? What were their primary occupations?
What would be your proudest moment?
What did your parents do that you are most proud of?
Describe family cars or trucks you remember as a child. What other forms of transportation did you and your family experience?
What are your earliest memories of radio and TV programs?
What nicknames did others give you? How did you get them?
Did you give any nicknames to others? Are any of these nicknames still used?
As a child, did you have babysitters? How often?
As a child, who were your best friends? Where are they now?
Who are your current best friends? How did you meet?
As a child, what games did you and your friends play? Where did you play?
Do you have some memorable camping experiences?
Do you belong to any groups or clubs?
What winter activities do you participate in?
Do you have any special summer activities?
Do you have any hobbies or collections?
What were the funniest and most embarrassing things you did as a child?
Did anyone read or tell you stories when you were a child? What were your favorites?
What sort of books did you and your family like to read?
Do you listen to music? What are your favorites?
Is there a book or song that was important to you when you were growing up?
What are your favorite books? Do you have a favorite author?
What one book would you recommend and why?
What were your most memorable family vacations?
What was the name of the first school you attended and where was it located? Is it still there?
Did you have a favorite or least favorite teacher? Why?
Did you like going to school?
Describe your typical report card in elementary, junior high, and high school. Did you get rewarded for good grades?
What kinds of mischief did you get into in elementary school? Did you ever visit the principal’s office?
Did you have classmates that later became famous or infamous?
Where and when did you go to junior high school?
Where and when did you go to high school? Describe the building. Is it still there?
How did you get to and from high school? What were your high school mascot, colors, school song or motto?
What high school activities did you participate in?
Who were your closest friends during high school? What did you do together?
What do you remember about special events like homecomings, proms, school plays, sporting events, and dances?
What did you enjoy most about school and extracurricular activities?
Did you attend college or graduate school? Did you graduate, and, if so, in what year and with what degree?
What did you want to be when you grew up?
How old were you when you got your driver's license? How did you feel about driving?
Were you in any accidents when you started driving?
What was the first car you drove?
Who taught you how to drive?
What was your first paying job? How old were you? How long were you there?
Who did you date during high school? What did you do on dates?
When and where did you first live on your own?
Who was your first date? How old were you? What did you do?
Do you remember your first kiss or a special kiss?
Who was your first love? How old were you? What attracted you to them?
How do you get to and from work?
Describe your cooking skills.
Describe your first family car. Where did you get it?
Do you remember your first or memorable argument with a significant other? What was it about? How did you make up?
How has your relationship with your parents changed over the years?
When have you felt closest to your parents?
Did your parents have favorite sayings?
Were there things your family did that your friends families didn't do?
What did your parents teach you that helped you succeed in life?
What has been your primary occupation as an adult?
When and how did you settle on a permanent career or job and on what basis have you been paid?
Describe your likes and dislikes of the job. Other than salary, what benefits has your primary occupation provided?
Is there another career that you wish you had pursued?
Who were the best and worst bosses you've had?
Who was the most memorable person you have worked with?
What was the funniest thing that ever happened at work?
What occupational and employment achievements are you most proud of?
What were the hardest, the easiest, the best, and worst jobs you have had?
What kinds of volunteer work have you done?
Describe experiences you have had investing money (stocks, bonds, commodities, real estate, etc.).
Have you ever gone into business for yourself? How did your venture turn out?
What are your plans for retirement? Will you change your residence?
As a child, are there certain trips or activities that stand out?
Can you identify events that you consider to have been turning points in your life?
Describe your spending and saving habits both as a youth and as an adult.
Have you ever traveled on a large boat or ship?
Do you have a fantasy?
Have you ever had a dream or fantasy come true?
Have you had a recurring dream?
Who has been your best friend for the longest time? When and how did you first meet them?
What do you admire and appreciate most about your friends?
Who is the most famous or infamous person you have ever met?
What are your favorite movies?
Outside of your immediate family, who has had the biggest influence on your life?
Have you ever visited a foreign country?
Can you speak a foreign language? How did you learn?
Have you ever had experiences with an emergency or natural disaster?
Have you ever administered first aid or rescued someone?
What was the longest trip you ever took? When, where, why and with whom did you go?
Are there mottos and rules you try to live by? Have those changed during your lifetime?
Is there someone you really disliked? Why?
Do you have any pet peeves?
Do any of you have identifying physical marks or scars?
What indoor and outdoor activities did your family do together when you were growing up? What were your favorites?
As a child, What types of entertainment were available for children in your home town and nearby communities?
As a child, what were your favorite sports and games?
As an adult, what were your favorite sports and games?
What were your favorite foods and beverages when you were growing up?
Did your family have regular restaurants or places to eat out together when you were growing up? What was your favorite?
What are your hobbies?
Have you ever collected anything?
What do you enjoy doing most in your leisure time?
What is your favorite dessert?
What are your all-time favorite songs?
Who are your favorite singers and recording artists?
What live performances have you attended?
What are your all-time favorite TV shows and TV stars?
What is your favorite thing to wear?
What is your favorite season of year? What do you like to do most during that season?
What is your favorite photo of yourself?
What is your favorite family photo from your childhood?
What is your favorite form of physical exercise?
What activities do you enjoy most with other people?
What activities do you enjoy most when alone?
Do you have a favorite place you have visited?
What is your favorite time of day?
What is your favorite joke or riddle?
Do you or a family member have favorite or funny sayings?
Do you have a favorite poem?
What are some of your holiday traditions?
What New Year's resolutions have you made and which ones have you kept?
Describe your current home, furnishings, and rooms.
Describe your current yard and neighborhood.
